text: The walls are where we played games as kids.
Those are the places where we lived out our childhood.
Our memories grew up on those walls.
We used to climb those walls.
There is a place next to the basketball court fences…
…that we climbed from. If you ask me if I could do the same thing today…
I don’t think I could.
It’d be tough for me.
For example, we had a passage there.
So we didn’t have to walk around the wall.
We used to go through that opening. It is about five metres high.
When you climb down from there, you are in the Rum Cemetery.
We used to sneak into the cemetery at night and play games there.
Everybody used to sit outdoors.
This area was completely empty. This park didn’t exist back then.
All the families used to gather here in the evenings.
Everybody brought some food, pastries, and cakes every night to share with each other.
We used to get in the tunnels inside the walls to play.
We would stay here until three or four o’clock in the morning.
I have never had a birthday party in my whole life.
I remember that one time I took a piece of bread with chocolate spread, put a candle on it, and climbed the wall…
…and celebrated my birthday at the top of the wall by myself.
I used to live in the old building behind that house.
I lived there for many years.
This is Avcıbaşı Shrine.
We have experienced many things here as kids.
Some of those were types of things that you shouldn’t talk about.
One day, 20 or 25 of us were sitting in front of the shrine.
We must have disturbed the shrine.
I tell this story very often and most people don’t believe me.
This side of the street was unpaved.
Let me remind you that 20 or 25 people witnessed this incident.
Since we disturbed the shrine…
…we found ourselves in the middle of something like a storm…
…when we moved to the other side of the street…
…while it was very calm in front of the shrine. We all experienced it.
The tree’s branches were shaking violently, as if trying to hit us.
It has been almost 20 or 25 years and nobody sits there anymore.
That is not because people are afraid or anything, but they know what happened…
…and they don’t sit in front of this shrine.
I remember the time when this park was built.
I was working at the time.
Nonetheless, I know of an incident…
…when the excavator operators ran away…
…without even turning the ignition off.
That is what I have heard.
As they were excavating, they came across something buried here.
There were two swords and three necklaces.
The necklaces had pendants engraved with the sultan’s icons.
The excavator operators took the artifacts and filled the excavated area…
…and then fled from the site.
They had even left the excavator running.
I heard that the police arrived later on but I was working at the time.
So I didn’t witness this incident but people still talk about it even today.
There were many things buried here.
For example, at the bottom of the walls…
There is a shrine next to the Palace of Blachernae.
There was a guy who pretended to be homeless.
He'd erected a small, three-metre long tent next to the shrine…
…and he dug the ground secretly from inside that tent.
There have been people who dug up graves.
They all were looking for a treasure-trove.
I tried very hard, too.
I dug up many places looking for a treasure-trove.
Did I find anything? The Prison of Anemas is…
a little further down from here.
The Prison of Anemas used to have…
How can I describe those to you?
The place had arched wall gates…
…and they were as tall as this three.
Although they have cleaned the place now but…
…the arched gates were filled with earth.
But there were small openings at the very top of the gates.
The openings were as large as this much.
There used to be cotton cords that were used…
in carpet manufacturing back then.
These cotton cords burn for a long time.
We used to light up a cotton cord…
…and crawl inside through that opening.
One day I found something that was shaped like a wine glass.
It had a wonderful color. It was parliament blue.
I took it home, cleaned it, and put it in a safe place.
We used to have chests at home.
We had two stacked together on top of each other.
God rest his soul, my dad and I moved the top one.
I wrapped the artifact in a clean piece of white cloth.
My dad said that we had to put it away so we placed it in the bottom chest.
We placed the other chest on the top. Around 3 or 4 o’clock in the morning…
…my dad came home from work and asked me what the dirt was on the living room floor.
There were footprints going toward where the chests were.
My dad and I removed the top chest and opened the bottom one. The artifact was gone.
I have never been able to find that artifact.
It was something I found and then lost.
I still wonder what happened to it.
What do you think happened?
To tell you the truth, in these sorts of cases…
…people talk about spells…
…they talk about jinns and things like that.
I think my experience may have something similar but…
…I have not been able to solve it.
When you rent your house, you move around a lot.
I am 44 years old and I remember living in 13 or 14 different homes.
I mean the number of times we have moved.
When I think if there is a house from my childhood that I don’t remember?
I don’t think so.
Which house was your favorite?
The one I loved the most was…
…our first home in Eğrikapı.
Why is that?
There was neighbourliness.
All the kids used to gather and play together.
We always played together, boys and girls.
We played until very late hours into the night but nobody said anything.
Everybody was outside anyway.
There used to be only one TV channel, which was TRT 1.
You couldn’t find anybody on weekend nights, especially on Saturday nights after 5 o’clock.
There would be a movie showing on TRT 1 and you couldn’t find anybody outside.
We didn’t own a television back then.
Actually, we didn’t own a television for a long time.
There was a pastry shop that had a DVD player and they played karate movies.
We, five or six kids, used to pile up in front of the shop’s entrance.
Whatever we were able to watch in 15 or 20 seconds, until the shop owner shooed us, was enough for us.
Then we would return to our neighbourhood and have pretend karate fights.
It used to be very nice.
I had jobs in both Sulukule and Balat.
I grew up among them.
So, I understand the problems of the Romani people, more or less.
Sulukule is full of rich people now.
We can’t get into places where we used to hang around. They are now inside apartment complexes.
You talk to the security guards at the gate and explain to him why you are there…
…but they don’t allow you to enter.
Whatever you do or say, they don’t allow you.
That wasn’t like that back then. You could go through Sulukule.
If you need some sugar today…
…you have to buy three or five kilograms from the supermarket.
That wasn’t the case in Sulukule.
You were able to buy 10 or 15 cubes of sugar.
You were able to buy 25 or 30 olives.
That was the case because those people lived day by day.
That way had its own unique characteristic.
Perhaps, I find that way of living more pleasing…
…because I grew up that way.
The way they were driven out…
For example, the bottom of the walls have turned into parks.
That is a good thing, no argument there.
But they just turn the land into a green area.
That’s all they do.
They build a green area and they leave it to its fate.
For example, look at this playground here.
Do you see a single kid playing here?
The playground is full of smokers and beer drinkers.
Aren’t there any kids in this neighbourhood?
Yes, there are! There are lots of them.
Perhaps the highest number of kids…
…the highest number of kids playing on the street,
…and the highest number of kids hanging around on the street…
are in neighbourhoods such as…
…Eğrikapı, Balat, Edirnekapı, and Karagümrük.
But there is not a single kid here right now.
This is an abandoned playground.
What good will it do if you built this playground or not?
So many people have met their other halves here.
People used to have wedding ceremonies here.
This used to be the place where we had fun in my childhood.
This area provided a picnic area within the city.
People used to go to Belgrad Forest for a picnic.
Families used to get together and drove to Belgrad.
Those who couldn’t go there came here.
There was a main road back then as well but…
…the traffic wasn’t as bad as it is now.
I remember very clearly that very rarely a car passed by.
These were the nicest places of my childhood.
I have been walking by this area for at least 10 years…
…but I have never set foot here. Thanks to you, I am here now.
I was obliged to set foot here.
